results.title: Mind-slaughter
results.brief_description: A look at the atmosphere of the earth and other planets as oceans of gases providing planetary life-support systems, and the consequences of an experiment to create an atmosphere for human habitation on another planet at the cost of existing life forms. Dramatically presented but fascinating comparative analysis, nonetheless, of earth and venus’s atmosphere - with a view to human habitation on the latter. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Mimi: an evening with Aboriginal Islander Dance Theatre
results.creator_credit: Reese/Smith Productions, Smith Productions, Andee Reese and Margaret Anne Smith
results.brief_description: Students from the Aboriginal Islander Dance Theatre perform several of their dance pieces which demonstrate their ability to perform modern dance as well as more traditional dance forms, with, at times, an innovative blending of the two.

results.title: Mime over matter
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel, Sim Productions, Kratky Film and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: Examines the use of pantomime to explore ideas and provoke open-ended discussion of such topics as man’s relationship to the material objects that make his life comfortable. Features Ladislav Fialka and his Prague Pantomime.

results.title: MIMA Yearbook. Vol. 3
results.brief_description: Volume three of a three volume set, this video compilation of excerpts of Australian film and video art covers the period from 1983-1986, and is a unique and tantalising entry into the non-mainstream history of Australian film and video.

results.title: Mima
results.creator_credit: Claude Kunetz, Paris New York Production and Philomene Esposito
results.brief_description: Mima is a French teenager living amid her loving extended family in rural France. Among these beautiful surrounds, she finds herself culturally conflicted, especially as her Italian grandfather has strong ties to Calabria. One day however her bucolic existence is shattered when her beloved grandfather is taken away by two mysterious men (Mafiosi) and never returns. Having witnessed the abduction, Mima is capable of identifying the killers, but is mute on the matter, fearing for her family’s lives. Mima is also pressurised to maintain her silence by her father’s killers and their cohorts, who are aware of her knowledge. Set in 1966, “Mima” is a beautifully rendered nostalgia and coming-of-age piece about identity, cultural displacement, family, and belonging. Existing between the worlds of children and adults, Mima can feel the demands of womanhood bearing down upon her as she is forced to make some alarming choices. Cast includes Virginie Ledoyen, Nino Manfredi, Margarita Lozano, Vittoria Scognamiglio and Patrick Bouchitey. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Millionaire for a pound
results.brief_description: A satirical impression without spoken commentary, of Surfers’ Paradise. Opening with colour shots of the idyllic countryside views approaching the town, the film quickly transfers to the gaudiness of the town itself with bizarre signs, neon lights and flashy flats. Features a tape-manipulated mouth organ and Beatniks! Rich with the iconography 60’s Australia, this is a fascinating document of the laconic, innocent charms that then characterised Australia’s favourite seaside idyll. Reminiscent of the surrealist social documentary work of Humphrey Jennings.

results.title: Millhouse: a white comedy
results.creator_credit: White Film Company and Emile de Antonio
results.brief_description: Newsreel and television footage is used to satirise the political career of Richard Millhouse Nixon. The film landed de Antonio on the director on Nixon’s infamous enemy list.

results.title: Millennium: tribal wisdom and the modern world
results.creator_credit: Richard Meech, Michael Grant and Biniman Productions
results.brief_description: The western world’s desire to change other societies to its own image has robbed our modern world of the gifts of other cultures. By exploring the values and different world perspectives that hold many tribal societies together, this ten part series aims to stimulate reflection and to look at what the modern world can learn from tribal societies as we all approach the next millennium. Written and presented by David Maybury-Lewis.

results.title: Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description: A five part series which analyses the Australian Constitution and its prospects for change in the 21st century. The programs discuss a variety of issues related to the Australian constitution, with each focusing on specific subjects that define the content of the interviews with and commentary from politicians, academics, media commentators and legal counsel that make up each episode. The subjects covered by the series include the history of the Australian Constitution and its founding ideals, the possible make up of an Australian Republic and the necessary adaptations to the Constitution, the Australian Parliament and the Executive as well as their distribution of powers, the rights and guarantees contained in the Constitution for the community, issues of aboriginal reconciliation in the Constitution and the future of the Constitution through the political channels for change such as referendums.

results.title: Mille Sept Cent Quatre Vingt Neuf = 1789
results.creator_credit: Alexandre Mnouchkine, Georges Dancigers and Arianne Mnouchkine
results.brief_description:
This film records a production of the historical play ‘1789’, in which the Theatre du Soleil re-enacts the French Revolution and its aftermath. It shows how the Revolution served only to replace one set of rulers (the aristocrats and nobles) with another (the rich), an analysis which is clearly influenced by Marxist thinking. Filmed in June 1973 during 13 shows presented on the stage of ‘La Cartoucherie de Vincennes’. Best print: X0131.

Credits: Producers, Georges Dancigers, Alexandre Mnouchkine ; director, Arianne Mnouchkine ; writer, Ariane Mnouchkine ; photography, Jean-Paul Meurisse, Michel Lebon, Eduardo Serra, Bernard Zitzerman.
Cast: Philippe Caubere, Mario Gonzales, Genevieve Penchenat, Jean-Claude Penchenat.
